results.title: A Look at sound
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
Very clearly, sometime using graphics, this film explains how sound works, how it is measured and what experiments have been conducted into its nature and effects. Some information about the work of Boyle and Edison is given and the physiology of the ear and nature of hearing are explained.

results.title: A Look at parliament
results.creator_credit: R. Barrington-Scott and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: Opening with the traditional swearing-in ceremony of the Governor of Victoria (Sir henry Winneke) this film briefly surveys the historic beginnings of the Victorian Parliament, including its architecture and design. From there it shows procedures relating to Victoria’s 46th Parliament. The work of the Governor, Legislative Assembly and Council, various committees and Officers of Parliament is viewed and there is a glimpse of the Parliamentary library.

results.title: A Long walk home
results.creator_credit: Brian Bosisto, Jill Robb and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The Flinders Ranges in South Australia are a remarkable chain of ranges and valleys penetrating the arid centre of Australia. The purity of its sunlight and colours is revealed in this study of the ranges and gorges and the flora and fauna of this ancient and fascinating region.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Bosisto, Jill Robb and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: A Long time to grow. Part III. Six, seven and eight year old society of children
results.creator_credit: L. Joseph Stone and Vassar College, Dept. of Child study
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Vassar studies: studies of normal personality development”.
Presents the social growth of the six, seven and eight year old child. They move into a bigger world, seeking the support of their own age group, through which traditional activities, games, magic and customs are handed down. At school, they learn not only the three R’s but something of human relationships. These children are marked by outgoing interest in the world around them, a powerful drive to acquire both skill and knowledge and the characteristic cleavage of the sexes in these early school years.

results.creator_credit_for_label: L. Joseph Stone and Vassar College, Dept. of Child study

results.title: A Long time to grow. Part II. Four and five year olds in school
results.creator_credit: L. Joseph Stone and Vassar College, Dept. of Child study
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Vassar studies: studies of normal personality development”.
While there is considerable overlap between four and five year olds and much individual variation, in general, fours are seen in a world of activities and interests which are a perfecting and elaboration of skills and interests of two to three year olds. Fives are beginning to enter the world of older children, a more formalised enlarging world, words and numbers begin to take on some meaning.

results.title: A Long time to grow. Part I. Two and three year olds in nursery school
results.creator_credit: Mary Fisher Langmuir and Vassar College, Dept. of Child study
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Vassar studies: studies of normal personality development”
The activities of 2-3 year old children in nursery school are followed through the seasons of the year and shows what children are like while they are learning and growing. It shows how teachers offer help by setting limits as well as by giving support and encouragement. Variety and suitability of play equipment for natural and constructive activity are indicated in the playroom and playground areas.

results.title: A Long time dream
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The diversity of remote Aboriginal tribes is vast and complex. Between them they speak fifty languages, live in 1,000 communities and number some 54,000 people. This program looks at some of the ways these communities have related to white society. Some communities live a superficially western style of life, yet cling to their tribal laws and customs. Others have developed social problems such as alcoholism by discarding their traditional lifestyles, some have returned to a traditional life-style and yet others are using western technology, such as radio broadcasting to reinforce and spread their own culture.

results.title: A Long shot that paid off: CSIRO's atomic aborption project
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Alexander, S.T. Evans and CSIRO
results.brief_description: The discovery in the early 19th century that chemical elements could be identified by observing their emission spectra lead to the development of accurate methods of chemical analysis based on atomic emission spectra. But it was nearly 100 years before Dr A. Walsh of the CSIRO Division of Chemical Physics started asking questions and became convinced that there would be many fundamental advantages in using spectrochemical methods based on atomic absorption spectra. Despite many technical difficulties and lack of interest overseas, Dr Walsh and his colleagues persisted and finally showed that the technique they had devised, had widespread applications in fields as diverse as medicine, engineering, agriculture and mineral exploration. Cinematography: Peter Bruce
results.title_for_label: A Long shot that paid off: CSIRO’s atomic aborption project

results.title: A Long night with lethal guests
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Geoffrey Barnes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Deals with malaria in New Guinea and research to find a cure. The film travels with a medical anthropologist to the rain-forest clad Schrader mountains where the Hagahai people live. The Hagahai people are being treated for malaria and other related infections transmitted through contact with the malaria-rife coast due to new road and air links. Researchers are looking at the way immunity to malaria works while treating people like the Hagahai.

results.title: A Long hour's walk
results.creator_credit: Sumner J. Glimcher and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: Father Rene Garcia walks through the outskirts of Bogota and discusses the poverty of both urban and rural Colombian working class. In the face of poverty, hunger, illness and premature death, can there still be hope?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sumner J. Glimcher and International Film Foundation
